segments.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ āyasmā sāriputto sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
segments.en: At one time Venerable Sāriputta was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

segments.pli: Tena kho pana samayena yamakassa nāma bhikkhuno evarūpaṃ pāpakaṃ diṭṭhigataṃ uppannaṃ hoti:
segments.en: Now at that time a mendicant called Yamaka had the following harmful misconception:

segments.pli: “tathāhaṃ bhagavatā dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānāmi, yathā khīṇāsavo bhikkhu kāyassa bhedā ucchijjati vinassati, na hoti paraṃ maraṇā”ti.
segments.en: “As I understand the Buddha’s teaching, a mendicant who has ended the defilements is annihilated and destroyed when their body breaks up, and doesn’t exist after death.”

segments.pli: Assosuṃ kho sambahulā bhikkhū yamakassa kira nāma bhikkhuno evarūpaṃ pāpakaṃ diṭṭhigataṃ uppannaṃ hoti:
“tathāhaṃ bhagavatā dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānāmi, yathā khīṇāsavo bhikkhu kāyassa bhedā ucchijjati vinassati, na hoti paraṃ maraṇā”ti.
Atha kho te bhikkhū yenāyasmā yamako tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā yamakena saddhiṃ sammodiṃsu.
segments.en: They went to Yamaka and exchanged greetings with him.

segments.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu. Ekamantaṃ nisinnā kho te bhikkhū āyasmantaṃ yamakaṃ etadavocuṃ:
segments.en: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, they sat down to one side and said to him,

segments.pli: “Saccaṃ kira te, āvuso yamaka, evarūpaṃ pāpakaṃ diṭṭhigataṃ uppannaṃ:
segments.en: “Is it really true, Reverend Yamaka, that you have such a harmful misconception:

segments.pli: ‘tathāhaṃ bhagavatā dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānāmi, yathā khīṇāsavo bhikkhu kāyassa bhedā ucchijjati vinassati, na hoti paraṃ maraṇā’”ti?
segments.en: ‘As I understand the Buddha’s teaching, a mendicant who has ended the defilements is annihilated and destroyed when their body breaks up, and doesn’t exist after death.’”

segments.pli: “Evaṃ khvāhaṃ, āvuso, bhagavatā dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānāmi:
segments.en: “Yes, reverends, that’s how I understand the Buddha’s teaching.”

segments.pli: ‘khīṇāsavo bhikkhu kāyassa bhedā ucchijjati vinassati, na hoti paraṃ maraṇā’”ti.
“Mā, āvuso yamaka, evaṃ avaca, mā bhagavantaṃ abbhācikkhi. Na hi sādhu bhagavato abbhācikkhanaṃ. Na hi bhagavā evaṃ vadeyya:
segments.en: “Don’t say that, Yamaka! Don’t misrepresent the Buddha, for misrepresentation of the Buddha is not good. And the Buddha would not say that.”

segments.pli: ‘khīṇāsavo bhikkhu kāyassa bhedā ucchijjati vinassati, na hoti paraṃ maraṇā’”ti.
Evampi kho āyasmā yamako tehi bhikkhūhi vuccamāno tatheva taṃ pāpakaṃ diṭṭhigataṃ thāmasā parāmāsā abhinivissa voharati:
segments.en: But even though admonished by those mendicants, Yamaka obstinately stuck to that misconception and insisted on stating it.

segments.pli: “tathāhaṃ bhagavatā dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānāmi, yathā khīṇāsavo bhikkhu kāyassa bhedā ucchijjati vinassati, na hoti paraṃ maraṇā”ti.

Yato kho te bhikkhū nāsakkhiṃsu āyasmantaṃ yamakaṃ etasmā pāpakā diṭṭhigatā vivecetuṃ, atha kho te bhikkhū uṭṭhāyāsanā yenāyasmā sāriputto tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ etadavocuṃ:
segments.en: When those mendicants were unable to dissuade Yamaka from that misconception, they got up from their seats and went to see Venerable Sāriputta. They told him what had happened, and said,

segments.pli: “yamakassa nāma, āvuso sāriputta, bhikkhuno evarūpaṃ pāpakaṃ diṭṭhigataṃ uppannaṃ:
‘tathāhaṃ bhagavatā dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānāmi yathā khīṇāsavo bhikkhu kāyassa bhedā ucchijjati vinassati, na hoti paraṃ maraṇā’ti.
Sādhāyasmā sāriputto yena yamako bhikkhu tenupasaṅkamatu anukampaṃ upādāyā”ti.
segments.en: “May Venerable Sāriputta please go to the mendicant Yamaka out of compassion.”

segments.pli: Atha kho āyasmā sāriputto sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yenāyasmā yamako tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā yamakena saddhiṃ sammodi … pe … ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā sāriputto āyasmantaṃ yamakaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Sāriputta came out of retreat, went to Venerable Yamaka and exchanged greetings with him. Seated to one side he said to Yamaka:

segments.pli: “Saccaṃ kira te, āvuso yamaka, evarūpaṃ pāpakaṃ diṭṭhigataṃ uppannaṃ:
segments.en: “Is it really true, Reverend Yamaka, that you have such a harmful misconception:

segments.pli: ‘tathāhaṃ bhagavatā dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānāmi, yathā khīṇāsavo bhikkhu kāyassa bhedā ucchijjati vinassati, na hoti paraṃ maraṇā’”ti?
segments.en: ‘As I understand the Buddha’s teaching, a mendicant who has ended the defilements is annihilated and destroyed when their body breaks up, and doesn’t exist after death.’”

segments.pli: “Evaṃ khvāhaṃ, āvuso, bhagavatā dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānāmi, yathā khīṇāsavo bhikkhu kāyassa bhedā ucchijjati vinassati, na hoti paraṃ maraṇā”ti.
segments.en: “Yes, reverend, that’s how I understand the Buddha’s teaching.”
They understand: ‘… there is no return to any state of existence.’
What do you think, Reverend Yamaka?
Do you regard the Realized One as form?”
“Do you regard the Realized One as feeling …
Do you regard the Realized One as in form?”
“Or do you regard the Realized One as distinct from form?”
“Do you regard the Realized One as in feeling …
“Or do you regard the Realized One as distinct from consciousness?”

segments.pli: rūpaṃ … vedanaṃ … saññaṃ … saṅkhāre … viññāṇaṃ tathāgatoti samanupassasī”ti?
segments.en: Do you regard the Realized One as possessing form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness?”

segments.pli: ayaṃ so arūpī … avedano … asaññī … asaṅkhāro … aviññāṇo tathāgatoti samanupassasī”ti?
segments.en: Do you regard the Realized One as one who is without form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness?”

segments.pli: “Ettha ca te, āvuso yamaka, diṭṭheva dhamme saccato thetato tathāgate anupalabbhiyamāne, kallaṃ nu te taṃ veyyākaraṇaṃ:
segments.en: “In that case, Reverend Yamaka, since you don’t acknowledge the Realized One as a genuine fact in the present life, is it appropriate to declare:

segments.pli: ‘tathāhaṃ bhagavatā dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānāmi, yathā khīṇāsavo bhikkhu kāyassa bhedā ucchijjati vinassati, na hoti paraṃ maraṇā’”ti?
segments.en: ‘As I understand the Buddha’s teaching, a mendicant who has ended the defilements is annihilated and destroyed when their body breaks up, and doesn’t exist after death.’?”

segments.pli: “Ahu kho me taṃ, āvuso sāriputta, pubbe aviddasuno pāpakaṃ diṭṭhigataṃ;
segments.en: “Reverend Sāriputta, in my ignorance, I used to have that misconception.

segments.pli: idañca panāyasmato sāriputtassa dhammadesanaṃ sutvā tañceva pāpakaṃ diṭṭhigataṃ pahīnaṃ, dhammo ca me abhisamito”ti.
segments.en: But now that I’ve heard the teaching from Venerable Sāriputta I’ve given up that misconception, and I’ve comprehended the teaching.”
“Reverend Yamaka, suppose they were to ask you:

segments.pli: ‘yo so, āvuso yamaka, bhikkhu arahaṃ khīṇāsavo so kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā kiṃ hotī’ti?
segments.en: ‘When their body breaks up, after death, what happens to a perfected one, who has ended the defilements?’

segments.pli: Evaṃ puṭṭho tvaṃ, āvuso yamaka, kinti byākareyyāsī”ti?

segments.en: “Sir, if they were to ask this,

segments.pli: ‘yo so, āvuso yamaka, bhikkhu arahaṃ khīṇāsavo so kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā kiṃ hotī’ti?

segments.en: What’s suffering has ceased and ended.
What’s suffering has ceased and ended.’
That’s how I’d answer such a question.”

segments.pli: Tena hāvuso yamaka, upamaṃ te karissāmi etasseva atthassa bhiyyoso mattāya ñāṇāya.
segments.en: Well then, I shall give you a simile to make the meaning even clearer.

segments.pli: Seyyathāpi, āvuso yamaka, gahapati vā gahapatiputto vā aḍḍho mahaddhano mahābhogo;
segments.en: Suppose there was a householder or householder’s son who was rich, with a lot of money and great wealth,

segments.pli: Tassa kocideva puriso uppajjeyya anatthakāmo ahitakāmo ayogakkhemakāmo jīvitā voropetukāmo.
segments.en: Then along comes a person who wants to harm, injure, and threaten him, and take his life.

segments.pli: ‘ayaṃ kho gahapati vā gahapatiputto vā aḍḍho mahaddhano mahābhogo;
segments.en: ‘This householder or householder’s son is rich, with a lot of money and great wealth,
It won’t be easy to take his life by force.
Why don’t I get close to him, then take his life?’

segments.pli: So taṃ gahapatiṃ vā gahapatiputtaṃ vā upasaṅkamitvā evaṃ vadeyya:
segments.en: So he goes up to that householder or householder’s son and says:

segments.pli: Tamenaṃ so gahapati vā gahapatiputto vā upaṭṭhāpeyya.
segments.en: Then they would serve that householder or householder’s son.

segments.pli: So upaṭṭhaheyya pubbuṭṭhāyī pacchānipātī kiṃkārapaṭissāvī manāpacārī piyavādī.
segments.en: They’d get up before him and go to bed after him, and be obliging, behaving nicely and speaking politely.

segments.pli: Tassa so gahapati vā gahapatiputto vā mittatopi naṃ saddaheyya;
segments.en: The householder or householder’s son would consider them as a friend

segments.pli: Yadā kho, āvuso, tassa purisassa evamassa:
segments.en: But when that person realizes that

segments.pli: ‘saṃvissattho kho myāyaṃ gahapati vā gahapatiputto vā’ti, atha naṃ rahogataṃ viditvā tiṇhena satthena jīvitā voropeyya.
segments.en: they’ve gained the trust of the householder or householder’s son, then, when they know he’s alone, they’d take his life with a sharp knife.

segments.pli: yadā hi so puriso amuṃ gahapatiṃ vā gahapatiputtaṃ vā upasaṅkamitvā evaṃ āha:
segments.en: When that person went to the householder or householder’s son and offered to
serve him, weren’t they a killer then,

segments.pli: Yadāpi so upaṭṭhahati pubbuṭṭhāyī pacchānipātī kiṅkārapaṭissāvī manāpacārī piyavādī, tadāpi so vadhakova.
segments.en: And when they got up before him and went to bed after him, being obliging, behaving nicely and speaking politely, weren’t they a killer then,

segments.pli: Yadāpi naṃ rahogataṃ viditvā tiṇhena satthena jīvitā voropeti, tadāpi so vadhakova.
segments.en: And when, knowing he was alone, they took his life with a sharp knife, weren’t they a killer then,

segments.pli: “Evameva kho, āvuso, assutavā puthujjano ariyānaṃ adassāvī ariyadhammassa akovido ariyadhamme avinīto, sappurisānaṃ adassāvī sappurisadhammassa akovido sappurisadhamme avinīto
segments.en: “In the same way, an uneducated ordinary person has not seen the noble ones, and is neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve not seen good persons, and are neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the good persons.

segments.pli: rūpaṃ attato samanupassati, rūpavantaṃ vā attānaṃ; attani vā rūpaṃ, rūpasmiṃ vā attānaṃ.
segments.en: They regard form as self, self as having form, form in self, or self in form.

segments.pli: viññāṇaṃ attato samanupassati, viññāṇavantaṃ vā attānaṃ; attani vā viññāṇaṃ, viññāṇasmiṃ vā attānaṃ.
segments.en: They regard consciousness as self, self as having consciousness, consciousness in self, or self in consciousness.

segments.pli: So aniccaṃ rūpaṃ ‘aniccaṃ rūpan’ti yathābhūtaṃ nappajānāti.
segments.en: They don’t truly understand form—which is impermanent—as impermanent.
They don’t truly understand form—which is suffering—as suffering.
They don’t truly understand form—which is not-self—as not-self.
They don’t truly understand form—which is conditioned—as conditioned.
They don’t truly understand form—which is a killer—as a killer.
consciousness—which is a killer—as a killer.

segments.pli: So rūpaṃ upeti upādiyati adhiṭṭhāti ‘attā me’ti.
segments.en: They’re attracted to form, grasp it, and commit to the notion that it is ‘my self’.
consciousness, grasp it, and commit to the notion that it is ‘my self’.

segments.pli: Tassime pañcupādānakkhandhā upetā upādinnā dīgharattaṃ ahitāya dukkhāya saṃvattanti.
segments.en: And when you’ve gotten involved with and grasped these five grasping aggregates, they lead to your lasting harm and suffering.

segments.pli: Sutavā ca kho, āvuso, ariyasāvako ariyānaṃ dassāvī … pe … sappurisadhamme suvinīto
segments.en: An educated noble disciple has seen the noble ones, and is skilled and trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve seen good persons, and are skilled and trained in the teaching of the good persons.

segments.pli: na rūpaṃ attato samanupassati, na rūpavantaṃ attānaṃ; na attani rūpaṃ, na rūpasmiṃ attānaṃ.
segments.en: They don’t regard form as self, self as having form, form in self, or self in form.

segments.pli: na viññāṇaṃ attato samanupassati, na viññāṇavantaṃ attānaṃ;
segments.en: consciousness as self, self as having consciousness,

segments.pli: na attani viññāṇaṃ, na viññāṇasmiṃ attānaṃ.
segments.en: consciousness in self, or self in consciousness.

segments.pli: So aniccaṃ rūpaṃ ‘aniccaṃ rūpan’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
segments.en: They truly understand form—which is impermanent—as impermanent.
They truly understand form—which is suffering—as suffering.
They truly understand form—which is not-self—as not-self.
They truly understand form—which is conditioned—as conditioned.
They truly understand form—which is a killer—as a killer.
consciousness—which is a killer—as a killer.

segments.pli: So rūpaṃ na upeti, na upādiyati, nādhiṭṭhāti: ‘attā me’ti.
segments.en: Not being attracted to form, they don’t grasp it, and commit to the notion that it is ‘my self’.

segments.pli: viññāṇaṃ na upeti, na upādiyati, nādhiṭṭhāti: ‘attā me’ti.
segments.en: consciousness, they don't grasp it, and commit to the notion that it is ‘my self’.

segments.pli: Tassime pañcupādānakkhandhā anupetā anupādinnā dīgharattaṃ hitāya sukhāya saṃvattantī”ti.
segments.en: And when you’re not attracted to and don’t grasp these five grasping aggregates, they lead to your lasting welfare and happiness.”

segments.pli: “Evametaṃ, āvuso sāriputta, hoti yesaṃ āyasmantānaṃ tādisā sabrahmacārino anukampakā atthakāmā ovādakā anusāsakā.
segments.en: “Reverend Sāriputta, this is how it is when you have such venerables as spiritual companions to advise and instruct you out of kindness and compassion.

segments.pli: Idañca pana me āyasmato sāriputtassa dhammadesanaṃ sutvā anupādāya āsavehi cittaṃ vimuttan”ti.
segments.en: And after hearing this teaching by Venerable Sāriputta, my mind is freed from the defilements by not grasping.”

sections.title: At one time Venerable Sāriputta was staying near Sāvatthī…

suttaplex.blurb: Venerable Yamaka had the wrong view that one whose defilements have ended is annihilated at death. The monks ask Sāriputta to help, and he asks Yamaka whether the Realized One in this very life may be identified as one of the aggregates, or apart from them. Convinced, Yamaka lets go of his view and sees the Dhamma.
